title: Navid Kermani
text:
Navid Kermani (; ; born 27 November 1967 in <a href="Siegen">Siegen</a>, Germany) is a German writer and <a href="oriental%20studies">orientalist</a>. He is the author of several novels as well as books and essays on <a href="Islam">Islam</a>, the Middle East and Christian-Muslim dialogue. He has won numerous prizes for his literary and academic work, including the <a href="Peace%20Prize%20of%20the%20German%20Publishers%27%20Association">Peace Prize of the German Publishers' Association</a> on 18 June 2015.
Life.
Navid Kermani was born the fourth son of Iranian parents in <a href="Siegen">Siegen</a>, <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>. He began his writing career at age 15 as a local reporter for the "Westfälische Rundschau". As a student he published in German national newspapers; from 1996 to 2000 he was a regular contributor to the cultural section of "<a href="Frankfurter%20Allgemeine%20Zeitung">Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung</a>". He studied philosophy, Oriental studies and drama in Cologne, Cairo and Bonn. His doctoral thesis has been published in English translation as "God Is Beautiful: The Aesthetic Experience of the <a href="Quran">Quran</a>".
He regularly publishes articles, <a href="literary%20review">literary review</a>s and <a href="Travel%20literature">travelogue</a>s, especially in "<a href="S%C3%BCddeutsche%20Zeitung">Süddeutsche Zeitung</a>", "<a href="Die%20Zeit">Die Zeit</a>", "<a href="Neue%20Z%C3%BCrcher%20Zeitung">Neue Zürcher Zeitung</a>" and "<a href="Der%20Spiegel">Der Spiegel</a>".
In the preface of his book "Between Quran and Kafka: West-Eastern Affinities" he acknowledges that he is an <a href="Oriental%20studies">Orientalist</a> and his world view has been shaped by his childhood interactions living in a German society.
Controversy.
In 2009, the German state of <a href="Hesse">Hesse</a> decided to award its 45,000 <a href="euro">euro</a> <a href="Hessian%20Cultural%20Prize">Hessian Cultural Prize</a> in July 2009 jointly to a <a href="Jew">Jew</a>, a <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a>, a <a href="Catholic">Catholic</a> and a <a href="Lutheran">Lutheran</a> to honour those involved in interfaith dialogue. There was controversy over Kermani's nomination as one of the three winners because of an essay in which Kermani had written about his feelings on seeing a painting of the crucifixion by the seventeenth-century Italian painter <a href="Guido%20Reni">Guido Reni</a>. The issue was ultimately resolved, and Cardinal <a href="Karl%20Lehmann">Karl Lehmann</a>, , Kermani, and <a href="Salomon%20Korn">Salomon Korn</a> jointly received the prize on 26 November 2009. Kermani donated his share of the award to a Christian priest.
Personal life.
Kermani holds German and Iranian citizenship. He is married to the Islam scholar <a href="Katajun%20Amirpur">Katajun Amirpur</a> and has two children. He lives in <a href="Cologne">Cologne</a>.
